Function is created with an expression that starts with the keyword function -> have a set of parameters and a body which contains the statements that are to be executed
Can have multiple parameters or no parameters
each binding has a scope which is the part of the program where the binding is visible
bindings defined outside the block or function the scope is the whole program - it is global
Bindings declared inside are local and can only be referenced for that function
Bindings declared with `let` and `const` are local to the block that they are declared in
Each scope can "look out" into the scope around it, so x is visible in sde the block
The exception is when multiple bindings have the same name, code can only see innermost one.
Blocks can be created inside other blocks with different degrees of locality
Code inside the ingredient function can see the factor binding from the outer function. But unit or ingredientAmount are not visible in the outer function. -> `lexical scoping`
functions can do everything other values can you can use it in arbitrary expressions instead of just calling it. Possible to store a function value in a new binding and pass as a new argument
Shorter way to call a function
Function declarations are not part of the regular top-top-bottom flow of control:
Expresses something like "This input (the parameters) produces this result (the body)"

"Call Stack" every time a function is called, the current context is stored on top of this stack. When a function returns, it removes the top context from the stack and uses that context to continue execution

Rewards and motivates us to take action - eat, have sex
Same reward circutiry but there are so many easy ways to get a reward. Too many easy ways for "fast rewards dopamine"
Dopamine comes into play - its the primary reason we have cravings and pursue goals outside of ourselves
2. Biologically wired to seek easier rewards to harder tasks - seek reward and avoid pain
Pursue multiple dopamine rewards at once - we can't do that. Can only focus on limited things at at time
Lights destruct our natural rythms and drain our energy levels
Our brains have not adapted to how our new world works.
Think of them like roads - it's bumpy at first but it gets better with repetition

1. Focus - Limit distracting stimuli, manage cognitive overload
2. Meaning - What gives my life meaning
3. Habits - Build good habits
4. Energy - Get back in touch with natural limits

Stay away from windows or other things

Tactic #2: Invest in noise cancelling headphones

Tactic #3: Change your relationship with your cell phones
Music with no lyrics or any
Switch from home mode to work mode

Fuse 2 seemingly unrelated things to get them to automatically trigger brain into work mode
We get dopamine hits everytime we look at our phones
It's primarily released when we're anticipating the rewards
Fast dopamine tasks - make us feel good and
We anticipate the rewards so we do it.
Tasks we procrastinate, we naturally shy away from them
Completing project is a huge hit of dopamine.
Dopamine & your phone - first thing you do when you wake up is check your phone.
How to accomplish our slow dopamines projects?
Most essential tasks to get done - critical to identify because they give you a definition of success to start your day.
Anything that is not considered an MIT
Fine to have, but don't need to take the whole day.
1. Prioritize a maximum of 3 MITs per day
This was at Seasoned who implemented this across the whole company - writing out MITs that is.
What does the 9:00 self need today to be happy with my day
What will my future self thank me for?
What was I hired to do?
Struggling to make out that list?
Employees increased individual productivity +28% and reduced burnout -42%
### Clear: Details what you are going to do
Example MIT: Revise slides 1-7 for Quarterly Business Review
## Procrastination is an emotional problem - we often feel fear anxiety  or stress around something and so we procrastinate.
If they don't have an achievement, it's likely that we will procrastinate.
We have a scale in our brain where Confidence and the Task at hand are weighted against eachother.
Make your MITs more achievable - break them into smaller more manageable tasks.
TIme-boxing: create 3 smaller time tasks for the bigger one you might not be able to finish.
Simply start and work on a task for just 5 minutes - due to inertia, once you start you'll keep going.
2. Ensure your daily MITs are clear, measurable, and achievable
Your dopamine will be double with the extra estimate
## 2. Overestimate your time it takes to complete MITs - at least twice as long as your estimate

1. Focus on completing your MITs over finishing to do list
2. Don't confuse being busy with being productive
3. Stop shaming yourself for procrastinating. Break tasks down and remove the barriers.
Task-switch makes your brain pause and reconfigure every time you switch
Focus Sprint: Completely focused time spent on MITs
Don't do any over 90 minutes at a time.
## Find and set aside dedicated time
Anticipation: Biological event: Cortisol kicks in and makes you prepared to take on the task.
Write out specific goals with time set in, but be realistic

```
        Focus Sprint
2:00-2:20 One chapter of JavaScript Notes
2:20-2:40 Two Leet Code Problems
```

````
Sahar's Focus Sprint
10:55-11:00: Scope out todos
11:00-11:20: Plan lecture
11:20-11:40: Respond to 10 emails
11:40-12:00: Review video script
```

Stop working and take a break.
Make focus sprints a team goal.
Biologicallly wired to not let down others - schedule sprints as a team.

3. Start Small

In many cases a function may need to yield the context of execution to another function, such as with generators

Preferred method for a genrator is that it will only calculate the next value when request through the method `next()`. command `yield` saves the current state of the generator function and return execution control to the calling function
generator picks up where it left off to calculate the next requested value

Sometimes you need to have a reference to an object but still be able to destroy it if needed - weak reference is one that can be ignored by a garbage collector. If the only references left to n object are weak references then the garbage collector is allowed to destroy the object and reclaim the space for other uses
Useful in cases where you have caches or mappings of large datasets that don't necessarily have to stay in memory

```
>>> import weakref
>>> class myobj:
		pass
        
>>> obj1 = myobj()
>>> obj2 = weakref.ref(obj)
>>> obj2 is obj1
False 
>>> obj3 = obj2()
>>> obj3 is obj1 
True
>>> del obj1 
>>> obj3 is obj1 
Tracebock Most..... 
NameError: name 'obj1' is not defined 
>>> print obj2()
	
```
Few different ways of serialising memory when you need to checkpoint results to disk - one is called pickling.
A complete module, not a command

To store data on the hard drive, you can use the dump method to write the data out. When you want to reload the same data at some other point in the future you can use the load method to read the data in and unpickle it.
One issue with pickle is its speed or lack of it
cPIckle provides the same basic functionality, but is written in C so it is like 10000 times faster

```
import pickle
data1 = ['a', 'b', 'c']
output1 = open['mypickle.dat', 'wb']
pickle.dump[data1, output1]
output1.close()
input1 = open('mypickle.dat, 'rb')
data2 = pickle.load(input1)

data1
['a', 'b', 'c']
data2
['a', 'b', 'c']
```

```
import shelve
myshelf = shelve.open('myslef.dat')
mysehelf['1'] = 'a'
myshelf['2'] = 'b'
myshelf.keys()
['2', '1']
myshelf.close()
myshelf.keys()
```

Python is an interpreted language so it must be compiled into a byte code format

`compile()` takes a string object that contains a collection of python code returns an object that represents a byte code translation of this code . The new object an be handied in to either `eval()` or `exec()` and can use `mod=` to tell compile what kind of code is being compiled. `single` is a single statement, `eval` is a single expression and `exec` is a whole code block

Declare bindings that are inaccessible aoutside a given block scope - also called lexical scopes are created:
won't throw an error if let is declared creating a new variable as the same name as variable containing scope:
let will not redefine an indentifier that already exists
like let declarations, they are block-level declarations which means that they are no longer accessible once execution flows out of the block in which they were declared
const declarations - can't be changed once they are set
Main difference between const and let is that trying to change const later on throws an error
But const declaration doesn't prevent modification of the value, only the binding
TEMPORAL DEAD ZONE: let or const cannot be accessed until after the declaration:
But you can use typeof on a variable outside the block where that variable is declared without throwing an error
Common to see this - in block level scoping of variables is within for loops, mean to only to be used inside the loop
In JavaScript the variable is still accessible after the loop is completed because the var declaration is hoisted - using let instead in the following will produce the intended behavior
1 is shared across each iteration of the loop meaning ufnctions created inside the loops all hold a reference to the same variable.
To fix this developers use immedaiately invoked function expresssions to force a new copy of the variable they wnat t iterate over
var has made creating functions in side loops problematic, b/c loops are accessible from outside the scope of the loop
simplifies loops by effectively mimicking what the IIFE does in the previous example
on each iteration, the loop creates a new variable and initializes it to athe variable with the same name from previous iteration can ommit IIFE altogether
Same is true for-in and for-of loops:
You'll get a warning if you try to change it
behaves similarly to a let in a for-in or for-of loop
var is used, it creates a new global variable it can accidentally overwrite an existing global using var

```
// in a browser 
var REgExp = "Hello";
console.log(window.RegExp);  // "Hello!"

var ncz = "Hi!"
console.log("window.ncz");  // "Hi!"
```
If we use let or const in the global scope a new binding is created in the global scope but no property is added to the global object

```
 // in a browser 
 let RegExp = "Hello!";
 console.log(RegExp);  // "Hello!"
 console.log(window.RegExp === RegExp)  // "False"
 
 const ncz = "Hi!"
 console.log(ncz);  // "Hi!"
 console.log("ncz" in window)   // "false"
```

Here is a counting abstraction that will be useful:

The  `countBy`  function expects a collection (anything that we can loop over with  `for` / `of` ) and a function that computes a group name for a given element. It returns an array of objects, each of which names a group and tells you the number of elements that were found in that group.

[](https://eloquentjavascript.net/05_higher_order.html#p_YjH+mbwxM+)It uses another array method— `findIndex` . This method is somewhat like  `indexOf` , but instead of looking for a specific value, it finds the first value for which the given function returns true. Like  `indexOf` , it returns -1 when no such element is found.
Use countBy to write function that tells us which scripts are used in a piece of text

## Summary

[](https://eloquentjavascript.net/05_higher_order.html#p_N6wo+JYLCW)Being able to pass function values to other functions is a deeply useful aspect of JavaScript. It allows us to write functions that model computations with “gaps” in them. The code that calls these functions can fill in the gaps by providing function values.

[](https://eloquentjavascript.net/05_higher_order.html#p_pZzOMOrxaO)Arrays provide a number of useful higher-order methods. You can use  `forEach`  to loop over the elements in an array. The  `filter`  method returns a new array containing only the elements that pass the predicate function. Transforming an array by putting each element through a function is done with  `map` . You can use  `reduce`  to combine all the elements in an array into a single value. The  `some`  method tests whether any element matches a given predicate function. And  `findIndex`  finds the position of the first element that matches a predicate.

JSON looks similar to JavaScript’s way of writing arrays and objects, with a few restrictions. All property names have to be surrounded by double quotes, and only simple data expressions are allowed—no function calls, bindings, or anything that involves actual computation. Comments are not allowed in JSON.
[](https://eloquentjavascript.net/04_data.html#p_9DCLKzKNiz)A journal entry might look like this when represented as JSON data:

JavaScript gives us the functions  `JSON.stringify`  and  `JSON.parse`  to convert data to and from this format. The first takes a JavaScript value and returns a JSON-encoded string. The second takes such a string and converts it to the value it encodes.

Every Lit component is. anative web component with the superpwoer of interoperability. WEb components work anywhere. youuse HTML, any framework or none at all. This makes Lit ideal for building shareable components, design systems, or maintainable, future ready sites and apps..

You can use Object.create to create an object with a specific prototype
Objects have another object to fall back on in case it is not there
The methods and properties an object has
can use "new" to easily create constructor
Prototype constructor through its prototype property
Actual prototype of a constructor is Function.prototype
how to write in class notation
You can omit class name in class expression
Overriding gives the standard function and array prototypes a different toString method than the basic object prototype
A map is also a data structure that associates values (the keys) with other values. Map names to ages
Passing null to Object.create the resulting object will not derive from Object.prototype and can safely be used as a map
Luckily we have a Map class - uses set get and has

If you do have a plain object that you need to treat as a map for some reason, it is useful to know that  `Object.keys`  returns only an object’s *own* keys, not those in the prototype. As an alternative to the  `in`  operator, you can use the  `hasOwnProperty`  method, which ignores the object’s prototype.

When you call the  `String`  function (which converts a value to a string) on an object, it will call the  `toString`  method on that object to try to create a meaningful string from it. I mentioned that some of the standard prototypes define their own version of  `toString`  so they can create a string that contains more useful information than  `"[object Object]"` . You can also do that yourself.

[](https://eloquentjavascript.net/06_object.html#p_HgUFdFB6vM)This is a simple instance of a powerful idea. When a piece of code is written to work with objects that have a certain interface—in this case, a  `toString`  method—any kind of object that happens to support this interface can be plugged into the code, and it will just work.

[](https://eloquentjavascript.net/06_object.html#p_qNZih5k+vu)This technique is called *polymorphism*. Polymorphic code can work with values of different shapes, as long as they support the interface it expects.
Have iterator produce objects with x, y, and z properties

Sometimes you want to attach some properties directly to your constructor function, rather than to the prototype. Such methods won’t have access to a class instance but can, for example, be used to provide additional ways to create instances.

[](https://eloquentjavascript.net/06_object.html#p_zLJ2u9mlXs)Inside a class declaration, methods that have  `static`  written before their name are stored on the constructor. So the  `Temperature`  class allows you to write  `Temperature.`  to create a temperature using degrees Fahrenheit.
New class inherits properties and behavior from old classs.

The use of the word  `extends`  indicates that this class shouldn’t be directly based on the default  `Object`  prototype but on some other class. This is called the *superclass*. The derived class is the *subclass*.

[](https://eloquentjavascript.net/06_object.html#p_mss/w8sDfy)To initialize a  `SymmetricMatrix`  instance, the constructor calls its superclass’s constructor through the  `super`  keyword. This is necessary because if this new object is to behave (roughly) like a  `Matrix` , it is going to need the instance properties that matrices have. To ensure the matrix is symmetrical, the constructor wraps the  `element`  function to swap the coordinates for values below the diagonal.

[](https://eloquentjavascript.net/06_object.html#p_9XrYhhYXI8)The  `set`  method again uses  `super`  but this time not to call the constructor but to call a specific method from the superclass’s set of methods. We are redefining  `set`  but do want to use the original behavior. Because  `this.set`  refers to the *new*  `set`  method, calling that wouldn’t work. Inside class methods,  `super`  provides a way to call methods as they were defined in the superclass.

[](https://eloquentjavascript.net/06_object.html#p_apvJjMYcsg)Inheritance allows us to build slightly different data types from existing data types with relatively little work. It is a fundamental part of the object-oriented tradition, alongside encapsulation and polymorphism. But while the latter two are now generally regarded as wonderful ideas, inheritance is more controversial.

[](https://eloquentjavascript.net/06_object.html#p_CWDhzksvzb)Whereas encapsulation and polymorphism can be used to *separate* pieces of code from each other, reducing the tangledness of the overall program, inheritance fundamentally ties classes together, creating *more* tangle. When inheriting from a class, you usually have to know more about how it works than when simply using it. Inheritance can be a useful tool, and I use it now and then in my own programs, but it shouldn’t be the first tool you reach for, and you probably shouldn’t actively go looking for opportunities to construct class hierarchies (family trees of classes).
